document.paragraph: I'm answering your e-mail in three different formats to illustrate how you would deliver a document using XML and XSL.

Actually, I only wrote this letter once. When I was ready to send it to you, I selected the output format using an XSLT stylesheet. I have two XSLT stylesheets. One to convert a letter to web format (html) and another to convert a letter to pdf.

If you are interested here are the original documents:
The original letter looks like this:
Original letter to Alex in XML. http://www.donandann.com/docs/test/xml/alex/xml.xml
The html stylesheet looks like this:
XSLT stylesheet to create a web (html) document. http://www.donandann.com/docs/test/xml/alex/xmlhtml.xml
The pdf stylesheet looks like this:
XSLT stylesheet to create an adobe (XSL-FO or PDF) document. http://www.donandann.com/docs/test/xml/alex/xmlpdf.xml

To send a itinerary or document in pdf from BCS or another system, you would do the following:
First, tell your system to create the document in XML.
Next, tell your XSLT converter to convert the document to the format you want to send the document in (html, pdf, or whatever).
Last, send it to the customer or vendor. Generally, you would send it as an e-mail attachment or as a link to the document on your web server.
Many software companies have packages to do XSLT (Microsoft, Sun, IBM, etc.) Their capabilites and prices vary by vendor and capability.
I prefer cocoon by apache. It's free and it does everything. The pdf converter is also free. No royalties, no licences, runs on any computer.

XSL technology isn't a secret. The specification is available for free on the Web. Every technology company is pushing it. It is simple for programmers because document only has to created in a single format (XML) and the XSL stylesheet does to conversion to text, PDF, HTML, or whatever new format comes up.
